The Magic Toyshop

Drama barn's current production of "The Magic Toyshop" is one of great theatrical prowess, it being visually spectacular. At times, the dark comedy is developed with fitting levels of awkward laughter and painful imagery on stage, a balance that was always handled intelligently, and to great effect

With the upcoming release of Burlesque: The Movie, we look at the history behind erotic performance

Upcoming Events

<strong>York Theatre Royal Young Actors Company Auditions</strong> This is for their latest production as part of The Yorkshire Museums Celebrating Severus festival. The production will take place around the museum from February 21 to 27, 2011. <strong>Drama Barn</strong> Week 7: The Magic Toyshop Week 8: Ta-Ra Love/Bye Bye Love Week 9: The Drunks <strong>Rene Daniels: Painting on Unknown Languages</strong> Camden Arts Centre, London 24 September 2010 - 28 November 2010 <strong>Undone: Making and Unmaking in Contemporary Sculpture</strong> Henry Moore Institiute, Leeds 30 September 2010 - 2 January 2011 <strong>Theatre Workshops</strong> York Theatre Royal 13 September 2010 - 13 December 2010 <strong>The Royal Ballet: The Tales of Beatrix Potter</strong> The Royal Opera House, London 14 December 2010 - 10 January 2011

Made In China

Ai Wei Wei and his <em>Sunflower Seeds</em>: The Voice of Chinese Contemporary Art? Sarah Jilani investigates

Young writers: too tame?

Debate ensued this year as playwright Athol Fugard spoke out criticising young writers for their apparent inability to write about morally weighty subjects. In his opinion the theatre world is lacking "committed playwrights who are prepared to bear witness to what is going on every bit as urgently as the old ones did"

Jeanne Roberts

A Hybrid World

When must the line be drawn between technology and the process of artistic creation, if at all?

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged!)

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged!) is ambitious, fun, dramatic, and pushes the boundaries of how we view traditional Shakespearean theatre.

Couldn't Ask For Another

There is no doubt that Rose Rea and Charles Rivington's production Couldn't Ask For Another is a sophisticated and successful endeavour

Happily Ever After Society presents: Return to the Forbidden Planet

Return to the Forbidden Planet written by Bob Carlton, touched down in York's own Central Hall last night, for the first of three performances by Happily Ever After Society

The Roar of the Greasepaint, The Smell of the Crowd

Full of insightful messages, belting songs, and often useless, but amusing, anecdotes, the Drama Barn's latest production <em>The Roar of the Greasepaint and the Smell of the Crowd</em> written by Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley, got off to a great start last night

The Intolerable Interment of Ignatius Briary

'Student written' is a term that, perhaps unfairly, has become synonymous in many people's minds with self-indulgent and over-ambitious. However seasoned writer and director Max Tyler's latest play, <em>The Intolerable Interment of Ignatius Briary</em>, is neither of the above

Arts in depth

"What do you mean he doesn't do email?" - Sarah Bolwell explores the work of the elusive painter Douglas Binder as preparation gets underway for his new exhibition in York next month

Up and coming events

This November, internationally renowned artist Rob Ryan opens an exciting major exhibition of new paper cuts and screen prints. Displaying the whimsical beauty that we have all come to know and love, these new works capture the distinctive qualities of the evocative hand-crafted paper cut, drawing the viewer into Ryan's world of romance (Thumbnail credit Rob Ryan, Your Job, original papercut, courtesy of TAG Fine Arts)

Frayja Winterson's Medea is a personal and powerful interpretation

Up and coming events

"On the last day of their quarantine, a wealthy couple's house is invaded by two strangers - a sailor and a girl who might not be what she seems. And so another month of quarantine begins." Or so the synopsis of Naomi Wallace's play 'One Flea Spare' says, which starts at York Theatre Royal this month (Thumbnail credit One Flea Spare, courtesy of York Theatre Royal)

The Mott Collection - "Loud Flash: British Punk on Paper"

The Haunch of Venison's current exhibition is an entertaining, raucous, brash, anarchic rampage through the rebellious era of the British Punk movement (Thumbnail credit TM0077. Chelsea, The Fall, The Snivelling Shits, Gig Poster, The Music Machine, London 1978)

Stomp

3pm. Ambassadors Theatre, Leicester Square. A surprisingly quaint and delicate little venue in light of the spectacle's reputation. On stage: caging, water butts, saucepans, drainpipes, stop signs, go signs, signs of a stomp-fest well in thumping order

Anne Boleyn

Howard Brenton's exhilarant <em>Anne Boleyn</em> provides a refreshing addition to The Globe's potentially dry summer season, Kings & Rogues (Thumbnail credit Miranda Raison in Anne Boleyn by Howard Brenton. Photo credit: Manuel Harlan)

Charm//Offensive

Suitable for sketch show veterans or those (like myself) who are not attracted to the work of 'comedians', <em>Charm//Offensive</em> offers exactly what its edgy label presents (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Greg Bartlett)

Into-Flora

Jewellery curator Kath Libbert discusses her latest exhibition (Thumbnail credit Artist Natalya Pinchuk's work is all about growth: Number Two Growth. All images copyright Kath Libbert Gallery.)

1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces

It is said that 'interactive art' is for children. After a trip to the Victoria and Albert Museum's current exhibition 1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces, I can only beg to differ (Thumbnail credit 'Ark' by Rintala Eggertsson Architects)
